message.content:
cs.PL, cs.LO, cs.TL, cs.DS, cs.SE 

This paper deals with the relationship between lambda calculi with explicit substitutions (ES) and environment-based abstract machines, which are commonly studied in programming language theory. Therefore, the most likely sub-category is cs.PL (Programming Languages). The paper also discusses the role of linear logic in the linear substitution calculus (LSC), which suggests that it could be classified under cs.LO (Logic in Computer Science). Additionally, the paper studies the time complexity of the executions, which could place it under cs.TL (Theoretical Computer Science). The distillation process used in the paper involves the removal of certain transitions, which could be related to the study of graph rewriting and formal languages, making cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms) another possible sub-category. Finally, the paper provides simplified versions of existing abstract machines, which could be of interest to researchers in cs.SE (Software Engineering).
